questions.text: The presenting diameter in mento-anterior is?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Submentobregmatic

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Mento posterior position
Uterine contractions 2 in 10 minutes

questions.text: A 34 years G4P3 presents in labor at 38 weeks. On abdominal examination, the uterus is term size and there is a single fetus in cephalic presentation with the FHR 130 bpm. Vaginal examination reveals the cervix to be 4 cm dilated with face presentation. Which of the following is a direct indication for a cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Mento-posterior

  • In mento-posterior positions, the head remains completely extended and the chin (mentum) is in the hollow of the sacrum.
  • There is no further progress of labor as the face becomes impacted as the relatively short neck of the fetus cannot span the kength of the sacrum
  • The sternobregmatic diameter (!8cm) occupies the pelvis and is impossible to deliver vaginally

 

 

Ref: Page no 312, JB Sharmas textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: In mento-anterior position, the head is born by
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Flexion

Mechanism of labor in Face (Left mento anterior)

  1. Engagement
  2. Extension
  3. Internal rotation
  4. Flexion (Head is born by flexion)
  5. Restitution
  6. External rotation
  7. Delivery of shoulders and body

** Just replace flexion with extension and extension with flexion in LOA**

 

Ref: Page no 311, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: A 28y G2 delivered a baby at home and was later shifted to the hospital for a vaginal tear 1 hour after delivery. This was the appearance of the baby on arrival. What was the likely position/ presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Mento anterior

  • This is showing a swollen edematous face of the baby
  • This is typically seen in face presentation (mento-anterior)
  • Other complication of face presentation are
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Cord prolapse
  • Increased operative delivery
  • Birth asphyxia
  • Increased congenital malformations
  • Prolonged labor
  • Obstructed labor (mentoposterior)
  • PPH

 

Ref: Page no 313, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: Which of the following fetal anomaly commonly presents as face presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Anencephaly

Risk factors for face presentation

Fetal

  • Anencephaly and iniencephaly typically present as face as the head is small/ absent
  • Tumors of the neck (congenital goitre)
  • Prematurity
  • Cord around the neck (multiple coiling)
  • Increase dtone of extensor group of muscles of fetal neck

Maternal

  • Grandmultipara (pendulous abdomen)
  • Inlet pelvic contraction
  • Obliquity of the uterus
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Placenta previa
  • Uterine fibroid

 

Ref: Page no 308, JB Sharma textbook of Obstetrics, 3rd edition

questions.text: An intern posted in the labor room is examining a multigravida in labor. She thinks that the presentation is face. Which other malpresentation is face presentation usually confused with?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Breech

  • Diagnosis of face and breech can be confused on vaginal examination

 


 

 

 

Ref: Page no 309, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Brow presentation
Deflexed head
Flexed head
Face presentation

questions.text: On per vaginal examination, anterior fontanelle and supraorbital ridge is felt in the second stage of labor. The presentation is?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Brow presentation

 

 

Ref: Page 313, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Plot a partograph.
Artificial rupture of membranes

questions.text: A 30 years G3P2L2 at 38 weeks presents with labor pains. On examination, the cervix is 5 cm dilated and the fetus is found to be in face presentation (Left mento anterior). The FHR is 140bpm. The next step in management is?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Plot a partograph

  • In face presentation, if mento-anterior, the patient can be allow to progress if the pelvis is adequate. In this patient, the patient has had 2 previous deliveries so we assume there is no CPD and can allow her to progress normally.
  • In persistent mentoposterior positions, there is No mechanism of labor
  • In this patient expectant management and plotting of a partograph is ideal

 

 

Ref: Page no 313, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Transverse lie
Occiput posterior

questions.text: An abnormal attitude is illustrated by:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Face presentation

  • Lie of the fetus refers to the relation of the long axis of the fetus to that of the mother.
    • Different lies are: longitudinal, transverse or oblique
  • Fetal attitude refers to the fetal posture—either flexed or extended
    • In cephalic presentation, different attitudes are
    • Flexion
    • Deflexion (common in occipito-posterior)
    • Partial extension (brow)
    • Complete extension (Face)
  • Occipito posterior/ anterior are examples of positions, i.e., relationship of an arbitrary point in fetal presenting part to that of various quadrants of maternal pelvis.

 

 

Ref: Page no 300, JB Sharmas Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Direct occipito posterior
Footling breech

questions.text: Which of the following DOES not have a mechanism of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Brow

  • Remember that brow does not have a mechanism of labor
  • This is because the presenting diameter (mento-vertical) is 14 cm and this large diameter cannot fit into any diameter of the pelvis unless it undergoes flexion or further extension
  • Conditions which have NO MECHANISM of LABOR are
    • Brow
    • Mentoposterior
    • Transverse lie

 

Ref: Page no 314, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: The fetal head is partially extended, vaginal delivery with chin posterior
The fetal head is partially extended, cesarean section
The fetal head is fully extended; assisted vaginal delivery
The fetal head is flexed, spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with a brow presentation. What is the characteristic attitude of the fetal head in a brow presentation, and what is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The fetal head is partially extended; cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • In a brow presentation, the fetal head is partially extended. This presentation is considered unstable, and the most appropriate mode of delivery is often a cesarean section due to the increased risk of complications during a vaginal delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 314, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: The fetal head is fully extended, vaginal delivery with chin anterior
The fetal head is flexed, cesarean section
The fetal head is partially extended; assisted vaginal delivery
The fetal head is flexed, spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in labor presents with a face presentation, and the chin is anterior. What is the characteristic attitude of the fetal head in this presentation, and what is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fetal head is fully extended; vaginal delivery with chin anterior

 

Explanation:

 

In a face presentation with the chin anterior (mento anterior), the fetal head is partially extended. In some cases, it may be possible to proceed with a vaginal delivery, if the chin is anterior and not posterior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 313, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma
